HOME
> Departments
![](https://www.northbergen.org/_Content/img/pages-covers/health-dept.jpg)

The North Bergen Health Department's mission is to improve the quality of life for our 60,000 + residents by offering a wide array of services that target health prevention, health promotion, public health safety and code enforcement. Within the health department lies the office of Vital Statistics.
Click here for Vital Statistics
.
The health department workforce regularly conducts inspections regarding residential public health nuisance complaints. Some of the most commonly placed complaints consist of heat, infestations of insects or rodents, overflowing garbage and/or debris surrounding property, illegal dumping, sewage backup, noise, excessive barking and domestic animal feces.
In addition, the department investigates food borne illness and outbreak related complaints pertaining to retail food establishments to ensure public safety and welfare to the residents of the community. The department conducts inspections for new and existing retail food establishments, public recreational pools, and institutions.
North Bergen is a pet friendly town that contracts with a licensed animal control rescue agency 24 hours a day/7 days a week. This agency operates a no kill shelter in close proximity to North Bergen and is also affiliated with other shelters in neighboring communities. Lost, sick, and stray animals always have immediate access to services. This agency also provides assistance with urban wildlife issues and animal cruelty.

To minimize the spread of rabies and ensure the safety of the population, the state of New Jersey mandates that all dogs have updated rabies vaccinations and be licensed yearly.
Please click here
to obtain the dog license application.

The township of North Bergen prides itself for hosting annual community events that seek to educate the residents regarding public health and awareness. Some of the many events include state sponsored free rabies vaccination clinics, blood drives, green fairs, and flu clinics.

Questions?

The property owner is responsible for removing garbage, litter, debris and feces on their property unless the owner knows who the violator is. The complainant has a right to face his accuser by issuing a summons and testifying in court that he/she observed the dumping.

Please contact the Health Department during working hours.

Step 1: Syringes must be clipped.
Step 2: Insert clipped syringe(s) into a rigid container such as a soda bottle or detergent that contains original screw on cap. Please make sure the container's cap is firmly secured.
Step 3: After making sure the cap is firmly secured, seal the lid with duct tape and place a warning label on the container stating: USED SYRINGES, DO NOT RECYCLE
Step 4: Dispose with household garbage and not in a recycling bin.
To view further information of safe syringe disposal please visit FDA.gov for
Safe Disposal Information
.
As per the NJ Smoke Free Air Act, smoking is prohibited in common shared areas such as stairwells, elevators, and hallways. People are allowed to smoke in the privacy of their homes. For more detailed information visit
Global Advisors on Smokefree Policy (NJ GASP)
.
Excessive moisture is a key contributor that causes mold to grow. Sources of excess moisture may be from plumbing leaks, leaking roofs or windows, high humidity, flooding or condensation inside walls due to poor insulation. For further information about mold visit the
EPA website
.

Under the North Bergen ordinance, property owners are responsible for turning on their boilers and providing heat to their tenants as of October 1st. During the day and night, the temperature within a tenant's home should read 70 degrees Fahrenheit.

The township’s excessive dog barking ordinance indicates:

The township contracts with an animal control officer for public property animal nuisances. We can refer you to him for assistance with removal of any wildlife animal issues, however, there will be a fee for services performed on private property. Please contact our animal control officer Geoffrey Santini for additional details at 201-822-7333.

If you know the violator's name and address the health department is able to enforce the dog waste complaint. If you would like to install a curb your dog sign in your home please contact the Department of Public Works. If the violator continues to leave dog waste on property please call us so that we provide you with guidance in signing a summons.

Featured Article


[Township Offering Free Rabies Vaccine Clinic for North Bergen Dogs and Cats on Sep. 24](https://www.northbergen.org/News/View/11113/township-offering-free-rabies-vaccine-clinic-for-north-bergen-dogs-and-cats-on-sep-24)
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Posted Monday, September 22, 2025

![ Township Offering Free Rabies Vaccine Clinic for North Bergen Dogs and Cats on Sep. 24 ](https://www.northbergen.org/_Content/img/news/Rabies-Vaccine-flyer-09-24-25_page-0001.jpg)


Mayor Nicholas Sacco and the North Bergen Health Department will be offering free rabies vaccines to North Bergen dogs and cats. Vaccines will be administered by Dr. Daniel Dima.

The clinic will take place from 7 to 8 p.m. on Wednesday, Sep. 24 at the EMS Building located on 1814 43rd Street. All pets must be on a leash/carrier accompanied by an adult who must be able to place the animal on the examining table.

All North Bergen dogs and cats must be licensed and licensing can only be issued with a rabies vaccination certificate. License fee is $11 or $8 if spayed/neutered.

Any questions, please contact the North Bergen Health Department at 201-392-2084.

![](https://www.northbergen.org/_Content/img/news/Rabies-Vaccine-flyer-09-24-25_page-0002.jpg)

Featured Article


Posted Thursday, April 10, 2025

![Free Cancer Screenings at the NB Rec Center & Library](https://www.northbergen.org/_Content/img/news/Cancer-Screenings-04-12-25.jpg)


Free Cancer Screenings at the NB Rec Center & Library on Apr. 12
New Jersey residents are invited to free cancer screenings on Saturday, Apr. 12 from 10 to 2 p.m. at the North Bergen Recreation Center & Library located at 1231 Kennedy Blvd.
Screenings are available to women and men who are uninsured without Charity Care and meet the following screening requirements:

* Breast (ages 40–74 or younger if higher risk), cervical (ages 21–64), and colorectal (ages 45 and above, limited to FIT tests)
* Prostate – blood draw (ages 55–69 or younger if higher risk) and colorectal (ages 45 and above, limited to FIT test

Appointments are required. Call 856-242-0590 to schedule. Screenings are for New Jersey residents only.

Featured Article


[Free Rabies Vaccine Clinic for North Bergen Dogs and Cats on Mar. 19](https://www.northbergen.org/News/View/10656/free-rabies-vaccine-clinic-for-north-bergen-dogs-and-cats-on-mar-19)
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Posted Monday, March 17, 2025

![Free Rabies Vaccine Clinic for North Bergen Dogs and Cats on Mar. 19](https://www.northbergen.org/_Content/img/news/rabies.jpg)


Mayor Nicholas Sacco and the North Bergen Health Department will be offering free rabies vaccines to North Bergen dogs and cats. Vaccines will be administered by Dr. Daniel Dima.

The clinic will take place on Wednesday, Mar. 19, 2025 at the EMS Building located on 1814 43rd St. from 7 to 8 p.m. All pets must be on a leash/carrier accompanied by an adult who must be able to place the animal on the examining table.

All North Bergen dogs and cats must be licensed and licensing can only be issued with a rabies vaccination certificate. License fee is $11 and $8 if spayed/neutered.

Any questions, please contact the North Bergen Health Department at 201-392-2084.

Featured Article


Posted Friday, February 14, 2025

![​North Bergen Issues Wildlife Warning Amid Increase in Raccoon Encounters](https://www.northbergen.org/_Content/img/news/raccoon1-July2022.jpg)


The Township of North Bergen is urging residents to exercise caution following a rise in aggressive raccoon encounters. In recent weeks, six residents have reported being bitten, prompting officials to advise the community to avoid all wildlife.

To reduce the risk of encounters, residents should avoid feeding wild animals, secure trash bins, keep pets supervised outdoors, and seal any possible entry points to their homes. If you see wildlife behaving aggressively or unusually, report it immediately.

For concerns during business hours, contact the North Bergen Health Department at (201) 392-2084. After hours, call the North Bergen Police Department at (201) 392-2100.

The Township is actively working with animal control and local health officials to address the issue and will provide updates as necessary.

Featured Article


[October is Breast Cancer Awareness Month](https://www.northbergen.org/News/View/10339/october-is-breast-cancer-awareness-month)
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Posted Tuesday, October 1, 2024

![October is Breast Cancer Awareness Month](https://www.northbergen.org/_Content/img/news/Breast-Cancer-Awareness(1).jpg)


In 2021, the most recent year for which data are available, more than 270,000 new cases of female breast cancer were reported. Breast cancer awareness is an effort to raise awareness and reduce the stigma of breast cancer through education on symptoms and treatment.

Other than skin cancer,
is the most common cancer among American women. Breast cancer is the second leading cause of cancer death among women in the United States.
are the best way to find breast cancer early, when it is easier to treat and before it is big enough to feel or cause symptoms.
The CDC offers free or
to low-income, uninsured, and underinsured women across the United States.
